docs.text:
My Favourite Recipes 
 Lessons


Collection of recipes from various sources


Categories:




Meat


Vegetables


Sauces


Bread


Cakes




Collection of Lessons a.k.a. Food for Thought


No matter how modest the meal, create a special place to sit down together and set the table with care and respect.  Savour the ritual of the table.  Mealtime is a time for empathy and generosity, a time to nourish and communicate.


Alice Waters, "Lessons from a Delicious Cooking Revolution"
docs.title: Home

docs.text:
Cakes


Simplest, Yummiest Banana Bread


easy, no mixer required


minimal technique required, very forgiving




1/4 cup (57gr) butter at room temperature


1/2 cup granulated sugar (reduce if adding chocolate)


1 large egg


3/4 cup flour


1/2 tsp baking soda


1/2 tsp salt


1/2 cup mashed ripe bananas


1/4 cup sour cream


1/2 tsp vanilla extract


1/4 to 1/2 cup chocolate chips / chopped walnut




Preheat oven 180 degree Celcius.  Grease pan with butter.


Beat butter and sugar till light 
 fluffy.  Add egg and incorporate.


Mix all dry ingredients (flour, baking soda, salt) evenly.


Mix all dry and wet ingredients.  


Bake for 30 minutes.


Tips:






Try different varieties of bananas for different subtlety of flavors.  






Sugar should be adjusted according to the sweetness of the bananas.






Personally, I will avoid 'pretty' bananas like Del Monte, and go for the less pretty ones from Malaysia/Indonesia, such as 
pisang berangan
.  






Don't hesitate to use 
extremely ripe bananas
.  'Bananas going bad' give you the strongest 
banana
 flavor.
docs.title: Cakes

docs.text: Simplest, Yummiest Banana Bread  easy, no mixer required  minimal technique required, very forgiving   1/4 cup (57gr) butter at room temperature  1/2 cup granulated sugar (reduce if adding chocolate)  1 large egg  3/4 cup flour  1/2 tsp baking soda  1/2 tsp salt  1/2 cup mashed ripe bananas  1/4 cup sour cream  1/2 tsp vanilla extract  1/4 to 1/2 cup chocolate chips / chopped walnut   Preheat oven 180 degree Celcius.  Grease pan with butter.  Beat butter and sugar till light   fluffy.  Add egg and incorporate.  Mix all dry ingredients (flour, baking soda, salt) evenly.  Mix all dry and wet ingredients.    Bake for 30 minutes.  Tips:    Try different varieties of bananas for different subtlety of flavors.      Sugar should be adjusted according to the sweetness of the bananas.    Personally, I will avoid 'pretty' bananas like Del Monte, and go for the less pretty ones from Malaysia/Indonesia, such as  pisang berangan .      Don't hesitate to use  extremely ripe bananas .  'Bananas going bad' give you the strongest  banana  flavor.

docs.text:
Sauces


Vinaigrette


At its simplest, vinaigrette is a mixture of vinegar and oil in a ratio of 1 part vinegar to about 3 or 4 parts oil.
 - Alice Waters




1 tbsp red wine vinegar


Salt


Freshly ground black pepper




Stir to dissolve, taste and adjust




3 to 4 tbsp extra virgin olive oil




Taste as you go


Why make vinaigrette when you can just buy?






Good vinaigrette is essentially good quality vinegar and good quality oil, which if bought separately, can be used for various other things.  Good excuse to try out different types of vinegar and oils out there, 
 experiment!






Once you get the hang of it, it makes the store-bought vinaigrette not worth the money.
docs.title: Sauces
